title: At what age did you start reading books or novels? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is quite difficcult to remember the exact age that I started reading books. But when I remember about the long journey, it has been quite sweet. As early as I can remember, maybe at the age of one or two, my mother read us stories from Magic Pot and Kalikkudukka. (The local children's magazines). They came on Fridays. I remember waking up early in the morning and waiting at the gate for the newspaper boy to bring them on Fridays and pestering my mother to read them out for me. They admitted me to a nursery when I was three. I was already in love with the art of reading. I insisted they teach me to read. I was too bored of playing. By 4, I was already reading magicpots myself. Apart from my parents, joining my school was a total turning point. They had a whole, beautiful library. But they would not let us borrow books until we were in 5th grade. We had to be satisfied with the fairytales and short stories that we would read in our class. The most exciting thing about entering 5th grade was getting to take books from the library. Even after so many years, I still smile when I think about those times. The first book that I read from my library was a short story collection. I don’t remember whose book it was or what was it about, but I remember the red cover like yesterday. My mother was quite suprised to see me reading something with so much interest. See, I never touched my school books. From there, I read a lot. A book every other week at first which went on to become even 3 or 4 books a week. Reading Harry Potter was quite a turning point. I fell in love with the magic of fantasy books. I could not wait to read more. When I think back now, there was a point when I had become addicted to it, like I really did not want to do anything ever in my life. My school was amazing. They had a beautiful library, and encouraged all of us to read. Everybody was enthusiastic at first, but when they felt that it was kinda dying down, they introduced a new scheme. Whenever we return a book, we had to write down a review of the book and get it signed by the librarian, to take a new book. It was school policy that you cannot keep the same book for more than a month. It was irksome at first, and people begged others to write reviews for them. But everybody was caught on the difference in handwriting, and their reviews ended up in a trash. And unknowingly, eventually, everybody in my class started reading. Even if it was just a Wimpy Kid, or the Goosebumps or Sweet Valley Twins or Famous Five or a random author, everybody read. There was always someone with whom you could talk about a new book that you read. If you buy a new book, there were already 20 people in the waiting list who are behind you every moment to give it to them the next. There were always new recommendations flying in class. By the time we were in 9th grade, we did not need the reviews anymore. The school understood that we were all keen on reading, and stopped pestering us for them. I remember this horribly rude thing that we did. Our social studies teacher was quite short, and the subject she takes being the least interesting among all, everybody had a novel open inside their geography or history textbooks. Surprisingly, nobody found out for a very very long time. I was quite scared to read a novel myself, because I felt like she was watching me 24/7, but I did read snippets from the ones my bench-mates were reading from. But our class-teacher caught us one day, and she confiscated every single novel that we had with us then. She got 41 of them after checking all of our bags. Note that my class only had 36 people. That is when I actually realized how much we were into this. We were all crazy about it. I changed schools after 10th grade. Till then, I really didn’t have any close relationships with people from other schools, but what waited for me at the new school was a huge shock. Hardly anybody there had ever read a novel. Many people who had just read half of a single famous five book were calling themselves readers. When I asked them about it, they all told me that their school did not have a library. Since then, I am forever thankful to my first school, for everything. They built up my life without even me knowing. School schedule soon became hectic because I was preparing for my medical entrance. There was no good library to take books from, and I didn’t want my parents to spend too much money on buying books for me, I started reading ebooks. Even though the schedule was dauntingly hectic, I was stubborn that it cannot defeat my love for reading. Even thought I wasn’t into it like before, I still read a couple of books a month. School life is over now. My interests in books have changed drastically. I am no more the ardent fantasy lover. I prefer realistic fiction, and autobiographies, non-fiction even. Maybe, it will change again in the coming years. But despite anything, there is one thing I am damn sure of, I would continue to read, all my life, no matter what.

I am currently 15 yrs old and i started reading books at the age of 13. I never had any interest in reading books or novels because they never had any pictures and i used to think that all of my creativity is going to die due to reading books. But I started regretting after I read my first novel “ Rich Dad Poor Dad ” it changed my whole mentality towards novels and today I often read novels and books based on creativity, personal development, technology, business startup, etc. Basically, my advice is that the best age to get started for reading novels and books is the age when you start writing essays in your examinations. This is a very beautiful way for developing one's personality as it develops both your writing skills and your knowledge at the same time. Hope this works for you

I was 10 years old. I remember very well. It was in the summer hols after 5th grade. My elder brother was already a book worm, I've seldom seen him without a voluminous book in his hands. But, back then, I wasn't really into reading. So, one day, I happened to ask him, just simply, abruptly, uninterestedly, what his first book to ever read was. Suprisingly, he remembered and even had it with him. He produced an old Enid Blyton Mystery series novel, from his ( now our) book shelf, thrust it into my hands, and left. And so began my daily hobby. Reading that 200 page kids book in 4 days was my biggest achievement . It's the absorption, you see. That anxiety to find out the next scene and the next. I still haven't reached my brother's level of vocabulary nor read as many books as he has. None in my family have any interest of this sort, it's just me and him. Our interests, desires, and perspectives are completely different from my cousins and uncles etc. My parents themselves don't read much, but they have never discouraged any of our interests. Oh, and there's one more thing I've always wanted to tell everyone I know and don't. A bookworm isn't necessarily an introverted nerd, who took to reading because he/she has no friends. lololol. It isn't true at all. I have lots of friends and I am unafraid of exerting my oratory abilities whenever necessary. My brother, dear me, is the biggest extrovert I've ever met.

I guess I started reading books when I was quite young. Most of my family are avid readers, so it must have been inherent as well. It began with fairy tales and fables. As the years progressed , I turned to books of fantasy and adventures like the ‘Famous Five' series, ‘ Treasure Island', the 'Harry Potter' series. In my early teens, I read a lot of classics like 'Pride and Prejudice', 'Jane Eyre’, ‘ Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde', 'The Three Musketeers’, 'Little Women',etc. It was during this time that I discovered my love for literature and began reading books in earnest. Today I feel as if they are an important part of my life. They tell me stories that move my soul and inspire my creative faculty. Their innumerable pages contain the essence of Life and encourage me to work hard and persevere towards my goal. They have also taught me important lessons about life, friendship, courage, loyalty, dreams, love and hardships. So, keep reading

There are two kinds of people as far as the art of reading is concerned. The one timers and the infinite timers. Definitely a classic like Pride and Prejudice, Sense and Sensibility, Persuasion and more precisely Lady Susan with a mature storyline and subtle social isssues requires a mature mind to appreciate it, definitely once you have already tasted the vinegar aspects of world. But a teenaged mind would be more than happy to just have been introduced to the wild foray of love dalliance so explicitly stated in these novels. Also a thoroughly mature novel like Madame Bovary and Arden Shakespeare’s Midsummer night’s dream requires time of life surpassing middle age. So you should decide whether you are one time reader or an infinite one and then take a plunge. Also make it sure that you have ample time to complete the novel and be with it through the thick and thin, both its juicy and sapless parts and also forgive yourself for ignoring for some days, because completing a sensible novel is no trifle.

“The scar has not pained Harry for nineteen years. All was well.” Hence, ended the adventure of the Boy who Lived. But was it a end after all? Perhaps the adventure of the boy who lived had ended but mine was starting. Hence, began my adventure of reading at a humble age of 9. It has been 10 years and still counting…. been around the world in 80 days with Mr. Phileas Fogg. Have entered the magical land of Narnia along with the Pevensie children and met Aslan, the lion. Had accompanied Percy to camp Half-blood, met a lot of Greek gods on his adventures and Witness the rise and fall of Kronos, the lord of the titans in the process. Had seen Robert Langdon solve the Da Vinci Code, saving the Vatican from complete annihilation and saving a mason from being killed. In the process learnt a lot about secret sects like Illuminati and Masons. Recently, have been busy tracing the steps of visionaries like Steve Jobs, Elon Musk, Chris Gardener etc. People often ask me, “After All this time?” and I reply in the affirmative “Always!” Signing off! Vagabond

Wow that is the best memory I can recall Till 10th I was not a nerd who studies rather I was a technical geek and computer games addict so after I got admission in Military School,Ajmer in class 11 after the 10 boards result and whole year just passed without very few memories of typical Boys hostel things like conversations,going out of school illegally,to screw some teachers blah blah blah In 12th I pondered upon it and find out that in 11 there were seniors above us and they made us busy with Ragada ( some physical punishment like push ups,chin ups,upside down and some sort of like that ) but now I was getting so much time ( As I hated the way our seniors did to us so I was not in the brat gang who bully their juniors ) and thought of making a new habit ( simply because we didn't have a mobile phone of ours allowed in the campus ) Let's READ ( it generates and rushes some extra energy inside my bones nowadays but it was not like that in the starting phase ) So my first book was an inspirational one Megaliving by Robin Sharma and Artemis Fowl and the book cheered me up to read more books  Then read many books since then in class 12th and now also reading ( have read more than 50 books despite of busy schedule ) Some authors which I like are 1. David Baldacci 2. Stephen King 3. Nicholas Sparks 4. Ravi Subramanian 5. Novoneel Chakraborty Mystery and horror genre writers like Nick Cutter,Ania Ahlborn,Paula Hawkins And inspirational authors like John Mason,Robin Sharma,Dale Carnegie,A PJ Abdul Kalam,Steve Jobs

I started reading at a very young age. From the time I could read English decently my parents started purchasing story books. I remember rading books in my 4th and 5th grade so I was around ten years old when I started reading. Although I do remember that my first ever full length novel was Oliver twist which I read when I was in 5th grade. I must say that although I didn't fully understand all the aspects of it, I really loved that book and thus I read all the Charles Dickens novels after that (which were similar to Oliver twist)like Nicholas nickelby, David Copperfield, etc. Most of the books available in our school library were Jane Austen and Bronte sisters classics so my reading had a solid start. Not to mention all the Goosebumps and Sherlock Holmes books I read. All this makes me so nostalgic. Nancy drew , Ruskin bond , Malgudi days , Daddy long legs..thats where one part of my reading experience ended. The second part started with harry Potter series and oh my God! I am one of those people who is still waiting for that letter(but I am 17 already so..)I am such a huge fan that my friend made me a Hogwarts letter and it brought tears to my eyes. So harry Potter was followed by hunger games , divergent and some other series. Then came the touching contemporary phase where I read everything from John green to .., well let's just say I read lots. Now I am on a break from books just for a while though because I am desperately waiting for that book release on November 7th and then we'll see. Byee

Well reading an array of books has certainly been an journey to me.All of it started when i was in 10th. Being an ICSE student i had, what i would consider, “decent” English. We had these English grammar classes in which we would be asked to write essays as homework and then read them aloud for the class and we would be marked on 25. It was in these classes that i felt the need to improve English and take it a step further;my English teacher was happy with my language and asked me to add finesse to it. I had this friend who had a taste for reading , you know novels and stuff. And so with a friend at my side with a similar inclination to explore language, i set on… And that’s also when i got addicted to reading novels. By luck, i had this folder full of novels; my elder brother gave me his computer when he left for his job. Started with Immortals of meluha,I literally ate that book in span of 48 hrs(I was on vacation at my uncles n that’s where i got hold of that book). delighted at the feat i requested my sister to get me the whole series;loved the experience. Soon devoured myself in Harry potter (I started reading it on the day after i had my hindi BOARD paper and gulped down the whole series before the exams ended that was in 20days) Harry potter became an addiction to me.I started reading it again but with little more maturity…considered and gave facts and characters profound thought, and understood the substance of the story. And I’m still on with my thirst for novels and books .

Books are the best friends one can ever find and reading is a therapy. So, what else do you need to read. It’s just a book.  Talking about myself I was a bit late when I started reading. I started to read when I started my undergraduation which was at the age of 18. But as I started reading, I couldn’t stop. I enjoyed reading and was benefited. Some of my initial reads were: THE ROAD LESS TRAVELLED  An amazing book which can change one’s perspective of life, opening him to optimism. The Girl On The Train  A psychological thriller novel by Paula Hawkins. A book for thrill and mystery enthusiasts written in first person.  Life Is What You Make It  The book talks about the ways of shaping our lives through the choices we make and not walk on the instructed paths of people.  Go Kiss the World  This book talks about the struggle of a person against the odds of life and him getting different lessons of life during the journey of the life.   There are a lot of books around. Each book says something. Explore some amazing books on MyPustak Portal for free.

I don’t think I started reading novels at very early age but yes, I started reading short stories at my very early age. When I was a child I used to finish my whole Hindi course book in one single day, the day I bought the book. Yes, I’m not kidding. I remember, shouting and calling my mother and showing her that I read the whole book. I used to read ‘champak’ , ‘nandan’, ‘nanhe samrat’ and many other books as almost every child does. I was no different.   Then, about when I was in third standard, I started reading comics, hindi comics. My favourite characters were Super Commando Dhruv and Nagraj. I got this habit from a cousin of mine who used to read them and was much elder than me. Ironically, I stopped reading comics 4–5 years earlier than I reached his age. Reason? Read below. When I went to my boarding school, there was a teacher who used to tell us the stories from R.K.Narayan’s Malgudi Days. That started creating a urge inside me to read books comprising of single stories. The habit of my elder brother also added to my curiosity and will. Btw, I went to that school in sixth standard.  When I was in seventh grade I read my first novel(it was for my age group as it seems after reading it). It was Famous Five by Enid Blyton followed by Secret Seven by the same author.  When I was in eighth grade, I read novel 2 States by Chetan Bhagat. That made me read his other novels such as Five Points Someone, Three mistakes of my life(actually I was curious to read about his second mistake which now seems very foolish and unworthy of curiosity), Revolution 2020, Half Girlfriend(later).  Till now, I have read several novels such as a walk to remember, the notebook, harry potter(first two parts), the murder of Roger Ackroyd, Tell me your dreams, Thirteen Reasons Why and many more. For last two to three years I lost my reading habit because of JEE preparations and I am trying to read as much as I can now. I have set a few targets to read particular novels and hope I will be able to complete them.   For now I am reading a book, that was a part of my class ninth curriculum which I felt boring at that time. The book is My India The India Eternal by Swami Vivekananda and one another book How to win friends and influence people by Dale Carnegie(these two are not really novels but books to learn few things). Besides I plan to read a several other thriller and love story novels.

There is no age for reading a book, you can start reading a book as soon as you learn how to read, or you can read your first book as you sit on your bed at the ancient age of 100. (Highly not recommended to start reading so late, but better than never.) I myself read my first book when I was nine years old. It was the age at which our school library starts lending books to children. (Alice in the Wonderland) It was a turning point in life, I protected the book like an over-protective mother. I guess it would be safe to say that it was my first love. After that, I am on my way to creating a library of my own in my room………………

Ah this is a really good question as my hobby and passion revolves around reading. My family and I went to the USA at round the age of 2..3? Well my brother, who was 2 years older than me, loved reading. And Me, wanting my mother's attention, copied him. So I guess I started reading at the age of 5, my mother would always take us to amazing libraries once or twice or twice a week since me and my brother dwelled at the top of the class and no tuitions so we had plenty of free time. My school was also very good, they encouraged reading. I read the Harry Potter series when I was in third grade. Hope this helped

I started reading books during my college days.My english professor used to say,to improve the reading habit one should start reading a book related to the subject one is really interested.Since I am from a business family(Hotel business),i started reading books related to business.HOTEL by Arthur hailey was my first novel.The author is really a rare breed among authors.He has written many novels.Before writing a novel he used to spend years in that domain.For example Airport .If you read that book you will know almost the whole day to day problems happening in the airport.How the men are overcoming them.All his works are classics.OVERLOAD is one of his best.This book is related to electricity board and how it works.The poems in this book are extra treat.

I actually started reading novels at the age of 11 years 11 months. (Hehe) (Can't forget, my friend gifted me that book for my birthday in advance) One of my friends offered me to read 'The Fault in Our Stars' by John Green, as she wasn't interested in reading at all. I used to read books (occasionally) then so I borrowed the book from her. I started reading it and I was left flabbergasted by the beauty of reading. I loved the book and it still remains one of my favourite novels. While I was reading it, I was lost in a beautiful world. I understood each and every word and felt emotions. I just loved reading. Next, I decided to read other books by the author and finally started reading. And today after 8–9 months from reading that book, I am still reading novels anf books. Thank You!

I started reading novels at the age of 10 and my first novel was Hardy Boys - Top 10 ways to die  And this was the start to Epic journey of an infinite world of books. After this I read about 10 Famous Five books but later I realised I was more interested in fantasy novels, thanks to Percy Jackson (My favourite fiction character till date and YES I love him more than Harry Potter) Now I'm 18 and till now I've read Percy jackson series including Heroes Of OlympusHarry PotterAll Dan Brown novels2 Agatha Christie novelsAnd some more…..

There is no particular age to start any reading . All in all you have to need patience and imagination for you readings. We have been reading since childhood and still we are continuing either in night time stories or academic reading or newspaper reading . Therefore, One have to connected thought the narration of the story rather just looking at words or ending the reading. It help in improving thinking , imagination , vacabulory and soon on …

21. And now my age is 22. Actually I started reading books when I was 18 except academic books. But I never completed any one those books. So I consider myself that the 1st book I ever read is the 1st book I completed and that was The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho. And here what is the special about this book, Mani Bharathi's answer to What small novel should I read for postive thinking? After that I had read many books. What is inspired me to read many books? A one good book

I still remember my first novel. I was in class four(don't ask my age) when I started to read. Fairy Chronicles Spiderwort and the Princess of Haiku (I won't suggest this book to anyone but kids) The next book I read was after 2 years(seriously) and it was Deltora Quest and the lake of tears after that I read another book after two years which was Mistery of the Friday Ghost. After another year(I.e in my class 9) I read The Return of Ratnavati and now am in class 11 and read all the Harry Potter books,complete Percy Jackson series and Heroes of Olympus series and a few more

I don't think reading books and novels has something to do with your age. It's a passion that one develops and can also be due to some other reasons. For me, I started just a year ago and I'm 20 now. This started because I wanted to read 2 States by Chethan Bhagat and visualuse the things he described. Now I read more instead of watching movie because I can imagine things as I want it to be.

I think it was when I was in class 3. I'd just moved to a new school and the library was the friendliest place there. It was full of books from a child's dream. Enid Blyton's everywhere. I'm sure there were others but I had eyes only for Famous Five and Secret Seven and Amelia Jane and Malory Towers and St Clare's and the Faraway Tree stories. I devoured them.

Actually i was not interested in reading novels. Nor did my parents allowed to read any novels . I remember once i tried to read a novel my dad saw that and scolded me saying is this your course book? he told me instead of reading these books you should have read your course books or solve some maths problems . I barely read one novel named half girlfriend , i read it almost half and then the story became bored and i left that. I was always interested in computers and cricket . I have never read a novel till its end either 10 pages or half of it . I found it boring

I was in my Engineering 2nd year, living in a matchbox like room with my friends, with no TV or even a smartphone or computer, so i found entertainment in Books. I started reading books to pass my leisure time and since then there is no turning back from them. They have been my closest friends and never left my side even in my sleep.

This question reminded me of my beautiful childhood memories!!! I started reading when I was 6 years old. There was this magazine named MAGICPOT which my father used to bring for me and it had short stories with animal characters and some activities. After the magicpot phase I moved on to CHAMPAK which was a very popular fortnight periodical then. I was first introduced to novels in my 5th grade when I started reading books by Enid Blyton and then moved on to Hardy Boys and Harry Potter series. As I grew up I started experimenting by reading books of different genres and also started getting into more serious works. And now reading has become a revered hobby!!

There is no Friend as Loyal as a Book. I Started reading at the age of 9. My parents made it a point that after dinner all of us would sit together and read a book for 1 hour. The schedule would be 1 book per week. Initially i use to feel that it was “useless” as i had to cut down my TV Time to read a book that did’nt interest me. Gradually after 6 months I saw some improvement in my Reading skills along with improvement in my vocabulary. Now this one habit that my parents inculcated in me helped me gain enormous knowledge along with vivid vocabulary. “PICK UP A BOOK AND START READING NOW’

Once during my school vacation, I happened to read one of my father's books. My dad has a huge collection of books mostly non fiction. And I believe that I inherited the habit of reading from my dad. The book that I read was “Notes to myself “ by Hugh Prather. That's the first time I read a book in a single sitting. And to answer your question, I was 15.

Well since 3rd grade, i used to read Tinkle comics a lot…then as years went by, i started reading horror/mystery type novels Like Sherlock Holmes, Goosebumps and many more..it was my favorite pastime and i used to read whenever i got time.. They helped me increase my creativity and i was very good in vocabulary and spellings.. I still read whenever im travelling …

A question that brings some of the best memories of childhood, I was a big fan of the small stories (Nancy Drew, Famous Five- read it all in class 5 :D) and then those that were published in our literature books in school, so reading began then and with time I used to read every small or big story I could find my hands on. My first proper novel and till today, most favourite one, was Pride and Prejudice. I read it in when I was in class 7th. I have got to tell you, if you read it, there is no chance you won’t fall in love with it.The book, the author, characters and the story always feels so fresh, no matter how many times I read it. Then there was no stopping. I moved on to Sydney Sheldon’s - If tomorrow comes, and then Dan Brown, Harper Lee, Maria Puzo’s Godfather and many others. Did I tell you that my Mom’s a big time fan of novels and so we have these different and lots of novels, so you can say I inherit this habit of reading a lot. :D

I started reading when I was almost 5 years old. I used to read Noddy series by Enid Blyton and then moved on to Secret Seven, Famous Five, the Adventure series etc and then to Hardy Boys by the time I was 6 or 7. And since then, there's been no looking back. Books and I continue to happen :)

I think from the time I could read, I have read books. My mother used to tell me stories but I started essentially with Bengali comic books and English children magazines like Champak and Chandmama. I have always been a huge fan of the festival edition of Bengali magazines which used to come out during Durga Puja in autumn(roughly late september-October). I have started reading novels at the age of 12.

I started reading when I was 6 years old. If my brain works well, my first read was Panchatantra tales. But I started reading novels at the age of 11. My first novel-read was Chomana Dhudi - K Shivaram Karanth. A Kannada novel.  My first English novel-read was The Sky is Falling - Sidney Sheldon.  I read this novel when I was 14. Though the vocabulary was difficult at first, I clearly knew how the story is running. This novel completely blew my mind. The novel taught me “ How to tell a story ?” By the time I was 15, I had read all books of Sidney Sheldon.

I think when I was 7 but, I majorly read Hindi novels and Comic books. I enjoy reading I wouldn’t say I am an avid reader because I don’t manage to excuse some time from my everyday schedule for reading but whenever I start a book I can’t focus anywhere else until I finish it. Reading gives me peace. By the time I was 15 I had finished all novels of Premchandra and Ravindranath Tagore. My first English Novel was Harry Potter Series after that the Diary of Anne Frank and Eleven Minutes I don’t remember the sequence after that.

I learned to read when I was 4 or 5 and honestly haven't looked back. I learned really quickly and remember reading all the books in my classroom when I first started schooling. I had a passion for reading from the get-go and it's not faded in the slightest even today.I've read some books as a kid but I would say that I really started reading and enjoying it was with ~12 to 19… some of my Good reads are Osho, Radheyshyam Ramayan, dale carnegie, Patrika publications and some comics of chacha chaudhary.

When I was 12, my friend introduced me to a children novel Diary of a Wimpy Kid. But my reading interest ended when I finished reading all the books in that series. Then after 2 years, another friend of mine gave me Night @ the call centre by Chetan Bhagat. Frankly speaking, I did not like it as I couldn't understand why he would expain every single thing happening around him. But after that I read his 2 States just because I wanted to know how it would be like to read a book that has been converted into a movie. And that’s when my beautiful journey with my even more beautiful companions (books) started. Since then I have read a lot of books and I still find time to read everyday.

It feels like a million years since I started reading. I guess I must be 7–8 years when I first started reading. But I remember the 1st book I borrowed from the school library. It was Alice in the Wonderland.

i have a great passion of reading books and novels i started reading books when i was 9 actually at that tym i dont used to read novels there were several other books like tinkle etc which i used to read i started reading novels when i was 15 and the first book which i read was the kite runner and this book gave me the pleasure of reading and after which i finished a number of books like the monk who sold his ferrari,the thousand splendid sun,brida,i even read books of chetan bhagat but they were not good one indian girl and half girlfriend

Usually I started reading books and novels at the tender age of 12 .. Even tough I felt a little boured in reading books but as it has now became a habit I feel it really interesting as I go through the story…

I started very young. We used to live in a joint-family in Kolkata; and all my cousins / uncles / aunts were bookworms…. I was surrounded by lots of books always. I remember having finished off reading 20+ English Classics by class IX. Started reading novels by Class VI.

If you ask about the age, I do not remember but yes I do remember the very first time I got my hands on any novel/book. I used to read comics viz. Archies (given to me by my elder cousins), Tinkle Digest, Adventures of Tintin. When I was in my 8th Grade, I read my first ever novel by Sidney Sheldon “If Tomorrow Comes” and thereafter I read all his books in a row. The very first book acted as an appetizer for me.

I usd to read books to my 2 year old niece. She used to listeen very carefully. Dont kniw if she understood any of it. If u start reading early to chilren they will gros up like books and not gadgets.i eead started resding at something like thst

I started too late. I was 1 1 may be. But it was one of the best thing ever happen. Though i started with comic books, i got hooked forever with Harry Potter. (i still read them) . Words cultivate creativity. My version of Harry Potter movie(Before even watching the real one) was better. My version of Edward Cullen was sexier. Books nurtured my imagination and letting to live in many of my dreams. Im forever thankful for that. I still read, reliving someone else life through books.

I read my first novel at the age of 13 .It was sidney sheldons’s bloodline.Initialy I faced some problem in vocabulary but reading novels helped me improve it to greater extent and i must say sidney’s novels are appreciable , i got impressed by it at once..
